title: Varicose Veins with Venous Ulcer
diagnosis_topic: Chronic Venous Insufficiency Leading to Ulceration
setup_script: A 54-year-old woman presents with a painful ulcer on the medial aspect of her left ankle. She has a history of longstanding varicose veins and works in an occupation that requires prolonged standing. She reports leg swelling and heaviness by the end of the day. On exam, you notice venous stasis changes around the ankle. How would you proceed?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/78 mmHg, HR 80 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.9 °C.
Dilated tortuous varicosities on the left leg, hyperpigmented skin, pitting edema, shallow exudative ulcer at medial malleolus.
Reflux in the great saphenous vein; deep venous system patent.
Ulcer enlarges with surrounding erythema and drainage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates compression and wound care
dynamic_flow.reply: Ulcer gradually begins to decrease in size, drainage decreases.
Wound swab shows mixed skin flora; if cellulitis develops, culture grows Staphylococcus aureus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident treats infection with antibiotics
If resident fails to treat infection
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient becomes febrile, ulcer develops purulent drainage.
Appropriate after ulcer healing for symptomatic reflux.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about surgical options
dynamic_flow.reply: Stripping, phlebectomy, or perforator ligation if incompetent.
Regular follow-up shows slow epithelialization; if healing stalls after 3 months, consider skin graft.
Importance of weight management, avoiding prolonged standing, and daily calf exercises.
Recurrence is common; lifelong compression therapy recommended.

critical_decision_points: Identification of chronic venous insufficiency signs
Use of duplex ultrasound to assess reflux
Initiation of compression therapy and wound care
Selection of endovenous or surgical treatment after ulcer healing
